choices.text: Simple myopic astigmatism - due to rays being focused on retina in one meridian.
Compound myopic astigmatism - due to all rays focused in front of retina.
Mixed astigmatism - due to formation of a circle of least diffusion on the retina.
Compound hypermetropic astigmatism - due to all rays focused behind retina.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents for a routine eye exam. On retinoscopy, you observe that light rays in one meridian are focused in front of the retina, and the perpendicular meridian is focused behind the retina. Despite these findings, the patient reports surprisingly good distant vision. Which of the following types of astigmatism is most likely present, and why?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Astigmatism and the Circle of Least Diffusion

  • In mixed astigmatism, light rays in one principal meridian focus in front of the retina (myopia) and in the perpendicular meridian focus behind the retina (hypermetropia).
  • Between these two focal lines lies the circle of least diffusion, where the blur is minimised.
  • If this circle coincides with the retinal plane, distant vision is relatively good despite the refractive error.

Explanation of Incorrect Option:

Simple myopic astigmatism - due to rays being focused on retina in one meridian (Option A): Here, rays in one meridian are focused on the retina and in the other in front of it. No circle of least diffusion is formed on the retina.

Compound myopic astigmatism - due to all rays focused in front of retina. (Option B): Both meridians focus rays in front of the retina. Vision is generally worse because there is no point where light is focused on the retina.

Compound hypermetropic astigmatism - due to all rays focused behind retina. (Option D): Both meridians focus rays behind the retina, and the blur is more pronounced.

choices.text: Differences up to 2% are usually asymptomatic and well tolerated.
Differences between 1-3% may or may not produce mild symptoms.
Differences exceeding 5% are generally incompatible with binocular vision.
Differences up to 10% can often be compensated for by neural adaptation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the tolerance of image size differences in binocular vision is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aniseikonia:
Aniseikonia is a condition characterised by a difference in the perceived size or shape of images between the two eyes. It commonly results from anisometropia (refractive error difference) or retinal factors (macular changes).

  • Tolerability of image size difference:
    • <0.75% → Usually asymptomatic (Rules out Option A)
    • 1–3% → Patients often experience definite symptoms like headache, asthenopia, and binocular vision difficulties. (Rules out Option B)
    • >5% → Incompatible with binocular vision; suppression, diplopia, or breakdown of fusion occurs. (Rules out Option D)

Thus, differences >5% are generally intolerable for binocular fusion.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK585108/

choices.text: Steepening of the central cornea due to healing contraction
Flattening of the central cornea due to peripheral incisions and IOP effect
Shortening of the axial length of the eye due to corneal remodelling
Pinhole effect by reducing peripheral aberrations

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with low myopia (-2.5 D) underwent a surgical procedure in which deep radial incisions were made in the peripheral cornea, leaving a 3 mm central optical zone intact. The goal was to induce changes in corneal curvature by weakening the peripheral corneal structure and allowing intraocular pressure (IOP) to alter its shape. Which of the following best describes the primary refractive change induced by this procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radial Keratotomy (RK):
 RK is a surgical technique used to correct low to moderate myopia (-1.5 D to -8.0 D). It involves making deep radial incisions (up to 90% corneal thickness) in the peripheral cornea, sparing a central optical zone (~3 mm).

Mechanism:

  • These peripheral incisions weaken the corneal structure, allowing the normal intraocular pressure (IOP) to push outwards.
  • The weakened peripheral cornea bulges slightly, leading to relative flattening of the central cornea, which reduces its refractive power and corrects myopia.

Steepening of the central cornea due to healing contraction (Option A): RK does not steepen the cornea; instead, it flattens the central cornea to reduce its focusing power for distant vision.

Shortening of the axial length of the eye due to corneal remodelling (Option C): RK does not affect the axial length of the eye or shorten the cornea; it only alters corneal curvature.

Pinhole effect by reducing peripheral aberrations (Option D): RK does not function like a pinhole aperture; this effect is unrelated to the mechanism of myopia correction here.

choices.text: Premature sclerosis of the crystalline lens

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of premature presbyopia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Presbyopia:
Presbyopia is the age-related loss of accommodation caused by decreased lens elasticity and sometimes reduced ciliary muscle efficiency. It typically begins in the mid-40s but can occur earlier under certain conditions, termed premature presbyopia.

Causes of premature presbyopia:

  • General debility (presenile weakness of ciliary muscle)
  • Premature sclerosis of the crystalline lens
  • Uncorrected hypermetropia
  • Chronic simple glaucoma (open-angle glaucoma)

Other contributory factors:

  • Diphtheria
  • Botulism
  • Mercury toxicity
  • Head injury
  • Cranial nerve (CN) III palsy
  • Adie's tonic pupil
  • Tranquilizer use

Uncorrected myopia (Option C):

Uncorrected myopia does not contribute to premature presbyopia. Instead, myopic individuals tend to experience less difficulty with near vision as presbyopia develops, because their refractive error allows them to focus on near objects without requiring additional accommodative effort. This natural focusing advantage delays the onset of presbyopic symptoms compared to emmetropes and hyperopes.

Reference:  

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560568/

questions.text: Which of the following systemic conditions is most likely associated with bilateral cycloplegia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paralysis of Accommodation (Cycloplegia):
Cycloplegia refers to the complete absence of accommodation, caused by paralysis of the ciliary muscle. Patients experience blurring of near vision, especially if previously emmetropic or hypermetropic. Other features include photophobia (glare) due to accompanying mydriasis and micropsia, where near objects appear smaller. Examination reveals abnormal receding of the near point and decreased range of accommodation.

Internal ophthalmoplegia, i.e., paralysis of ciliary muscle and sphincter pupillae, may result from:

  • Diabetes mellitus → due to neuritis affecting the ciliary nerve.
  • Syphilis → as part of neurosyphilis involving cranial nerves.
  • Diphtheria → post-infectious neuritis causing bilateral involvement.

choices.text: Pupillary axis and line of sight

questions.text: The angle kappa (k) is formed between:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Angle Kappa (κ) is an important ocular angle that forms between the visual axis and the pupillary axis. It is measured clinically as the distance between the centre of the pupil and the corneal light reflex. This angle is significant for assessing eye alignment and diagnosing pseudostrabismus.

  • A positive kappa angle is noted when the light reflex is nasal to the centre of the pupil, often seen in pseudostrabismus.
  • This is a clinically relevant angle for determining ocular misalignment.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Optical axis and Fixation axis (Option A): This defines Angle Gamma, not Angle Kappa.
Angle Gamma is the angle between the optical axis and the fixation axis at the centre of rotation of the eyeball.

Optical axis and Visual axis (Option B): This defines Angle Alpha, not Kappa. Angle Alpha is the angle between the optical axis and the visual axis at the nodal point.

Pupillary axis and line of sight (Option D): This defines Angle Lambda, which is almost similar to Kappa but refers to the line of sight instead of the visual axis.

questions.text: Which cycloplegic drug has the fastest onset of action but is not preferred for retinoscopy due to its short duration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tropicamide (1% drops) has a peak effect in 20-40 minutes
  • Atropine takes 2-3 days to reach peak effect (Rules out Option A)
  • Cyclopentolate has a peak effect of 80-90 minutes (Rules out Option C)
  • Homatropine reaches peak effect in 60-90 minutes (Rules out Option D)

choices.text: Axis of the cylinder to be prescribed
Power of the cylinder to be prescribed
Both axis and power of the cylinder

questions.text: While performing subjective verification of refraction, the cross cylinder is used to check:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Jackson's Cross-Cylinder Technique is a standard method used during subjective refraction to fine-tune cylindrical correction. It involves determining both the axis and the power of the cylinder in the trial frame to achieve the best visual clarity for astigmatic patients.
  • The cross-cylinder is first used to refine the axis by rotating the lens to align with the correct orientation for cylindrical power.
  • Next, it is used to refine the power by adjusting and verifying which strength improves the patient's visual acuity.
  • Therefore, both axis and power are determined using this technique.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Axis of the cylinder to be prescribed (Option A): While axis refinement is indeed part of the process, the cross-cylinder is not limited to axis determination; it is equally important for verifying cylindrical power.

Power of the cylinder to be prescribed (Option B): Although the power refinement is a key step, axis determination is performed first before adjusting power. This option incompletely represents the cross-cylinder's role.

questions.text: Flexible intraocular lenses (IOLs) used in modern cataract surgery are made of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flexible IOLs are designed for injector-based delivery and small incisions, allowing them to unroll inside the eye. These are made from hydrophobic acrylic, hydrophilic acrylic (hydrogel), silicone, and collamer.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) Option (C): PMMA is used for rigid IOLs, which require a larger incision and cannot be folded or injected. It does not fall under flexible IOL materials.

questions.text: Excessive accommodation leads to a temporary shift in refractive state due to the spasm of the ciliary muscle. This condition is best described as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudomyopia occurs because prolonged or involuntary ciliary muscle contraction causes a transient increase in the eye’s refractive power, leading to false myopia.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hypermetropia (Option A): Hypermetropia is the inability of the eye to bring parallel rays into focus on the retina due to a shorter axial length or weaker refractive elements. Excessive accommodation does not cause hypermetropia; in fact, it compensates for it.

True myopia (Option B): True myopia is due to structural causes (e.g., increased axial length or curvature) and is permanent. Pseudomyopia is functional and reversible when accommodation spasm resolves.

Consecutive myopia (Option D): Consecutive myopia arises after surgical overcorrection of hypermetropia or pseudophakia with an overcorrecting intraocular lens (IOL). It is unrelated to accommodation.

choices.text: Decreased elasticity of the lens capsule and increasing lens sclerosis
Weakness of the suspensory ligaments reduces lens mobility
Decline in ciliary muscle power with age

questions.text: In the pathophysiology of presbyopia, which of the following age-related changes primarily contributes to the progressive loss of accommodation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Presbyopia primarily stems from two age-related changes in the eye's lens: a reduction in the flexibility of the lens capsule and a progressive hardening and increase in size of the lens material (sclerosis). Furthermore, a weakening of the ciliary muscle with age can also contribute to this condition. These combined factors diminish the eye's power to focus, leading to the symptoms of presbyopia.

Weakness of the suspensory ligaments is not considered a cause of presbyopia. The condition primarily stems from problems with lens elasticity and ciliary muscle function, rather than issues with the zonules. (Rules out Option B)

choices.text: Manifest hypermetropia is the part of total hypermetropia revealed during routine refraction and is subdivided into facultative and absolute hypermetropia.
Latent hypermetropia results from tonic contraction of the ciliary muscle and can only be revealed after cycloplegia.
Absolute hypermetropia is the residual portion of hypermetropia that cannot be neutralised by accommodation.
Facultative hypermetropia is the portion of hypermetropia that cannot be corrected by accommodation and needs convex lenses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about types of hypermetropia is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Facultative hypermetropia refers to the part of manifest hypermetropia that can be corrected by accommodation. (Option D is incorrect)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Manifest hypermetropia (Option A): Manifest hypermetropia refers to the amount of farsightedness that's detectable during a standard eye exam. It's composed of two parts:

  • Facultative hypermetropia: This is the portion of hypermetropia that the eye can overcome through its natural focusing ability (accommodation).
  • Absolute hypermetropia: This part of hypermetropia cannot be corrected by the eye's own accommodation.

Latent hypermetropia (Option B): Latent hypermetropia is farsightedness that stays hidden due to the ciliary muscle's inherent tension. It's only uncovered after cycloplegia, a procedure that temporarily paralyses this muscle.

Absolute hypermetropia (Option C): Even with maximum effort from the eye's focusing mechanism, absolute hypermetropia persists. It represents the component of manifest hypermetropia that the power of accommodation cannot overcome

questions.text: Which of the following components of the eye has the highest refractive index?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lens core has a refractive index of 1.406, which is the highest among all components of the optical system

questions.text: The reduced eye model simplifies the optical system of the human eye by using a single principal point and nodal point. Based on this model, the total refractive power of the reduced eye in its relaxed state is approximately:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The reduced eye simplifies the complex optics of the human eye by considering a single principal and nodal point. In this model, the total refractive power in the relaxed (unaccommodated) state is +58.2 D

  • In the reduced eye model, Listing calculated the total refractive power using:
  • F = Refractive index of vitreous/ Posterior focal length in meters
  • Substituting values: F = (1.336×1000)/22.9 = 58.2D
  • This value represents the combined refractive power of the cornea and lens in the simplified system.

questions.text: A female patient requests LASIK surgery for her refractive error correction. Which of the following is a contraindication for performing LASIK in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

LASIK is generally not advised for children and adolescents because of ongoing changes in refraction during adolescence. Performing LASIK at this age may lead to refractive instability and poor outcomes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Myopia of 4 diopters (Option A): LASIK is indicated for low to moderate myopia, typically ranging from -0.5 D to -9.00 D. A myopia of 4 diopters falls well within this range and is not a contraindication.

Stable refraction for 1 year (Option C): A stable refraction for ≥1 year is a prerequisite for LASIK. Refractive instability (change >0.5 D in the last year) is a contraindication, but here the stability makes the patient suitable for surgery.

Corneal thickness of 600 microns (Option D):
A normal corneal thickness (~540-550 microns) is required for LASIK. A thickness of 600 microns is well above the minimum requirement and does not pose any contraindication.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555970/

questions.text: At what age is the amplitude of accommodation at its maximum, allowing the eyes to focus on near objects with greatest efficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The amplitude of accommodation, which refers to how much the eye can adjust its focus for near objects, is highest in early childhood (Option D). As age advances, the near point (the closest point of clear focus) moves further away (Rules out Option A, B & C). For instance, at around 20 years of age, the near point is roughly 10 cm, but by 50 years, it shifts back to approximately 50 cm.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK542189/

questions.text: The first line of management for refractive errors, including high myopia (-10D), is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glasses are the first line of treatment and can correct virtually all refractive errors, including high myopia, except in cases of irregular astigmatism. They are non-invasive, cost-effective, and suitable for initial management before considering surgical options.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Contact lenses (Option A): Although soft and rigid contact lenses are highly effective for refractive errors, they are considered an alternative to glasses and not the first line of management. Contact lenses are usually prescribed for patients requiring better peripheral vision or in cases where glasses are not tolerated.

Refractive lens exchange (Option C): This is a surgical option and is not used as the initial management for refractive errors. It involves removing the natural lens and is reserved for specific situations like very high refractive errors or when accommodating power is not needed (older patients).

Rigid gas permeable lenses (Option D): Rigid lenses are excellent for correcting irregular astigmatism and providing sharper vision than soft lenses. However, they are not the first line of treatment and are typically reserved for cases like keratoconus or when soft lenses fail.

Key Takeaway

  • Glasses remain the first line of treatment for most refractive errors, including high myopia.
  • Contact lenses and surgical options are reserved for patients who cannot tolerate glasses or require additional correction (e.g., irregular astigmatism).
